I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $40,000,000 in Everbridge Partners Fund I, L.P. (Everbridge I).1  
 
2.  The proposed investment in Everbridge I will provide growth capital to about ten middle-
market companies operating primarily in the health care, business services, and consumer 
sectors, in India, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), and Southeast Asia (Indonesia, Malaysia, 
the Philippines, and Thailand).2 These companies often lack access to affordable capital because 
equity financing is generally limited and traditional bank financing is difficult to source without hard 
assets that can be pledged as collateral. Furthermore, many companies in emerging Asia need 
improved professional management to scale up their operations. The proposed investment by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Everbridge I would help deepen capital markets and support 
Asia’s growing private sector.3 
 
3.  Everbridge I will be established as a Cayman Islands limited partnership, which will invest, 
via Everbridge Partners Master Fund I Private Limited, the Singapore master fund (together: the 
fund), in companies with substantial operations in Asia.4 Everbridge Partners Private Limited 
(together with its affiliates: Everbridge), a Singapore company, will be the fund manager. The 
fund’s target capitalization is $750 million.  
 
II.  THE FUND 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
4.  Description. Everbridge is a newly formed investment management firm spun out of a 
leading private equity firm, Capital Group Private Markets (CGPM). CGPM is part of Capital 
Group, a financial services company with its headquarters in the United States, specializing in 
mutual funds, private equity, and investment services (7,500 employees, $1.8 trillion of assets 
under management). Everbridge was founded by the ex-managing partner of CGPM Asia, 
Leonard Kim, who now leads a team of ex-CGPM employees.5 Everbridge is headquartered in 
Singapore and has an additional office in Beijing. The Everbridge team (through CGPM) has a 
20-year history (since 1998) investing across multiple market and economic cycles in Asia. [This 
information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to 
Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].6

6.  Investment  identification.  Through  the  market  mapping  of  Asia’s  private  equity 
landscape, ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) first met the Everbridge team 
in September 2018 and has been in regular contact with Leonard Kim and his team since then. 
PSOD  has  identified  Everbridge’s  profile  to  be  consistent  with  ADB’s  private  equity  fund 
investment guidelines: 
(i)  it is one of the more experienced fund management teams in Asia with an 
extensive 20-year track record (through CGPM); 
(ii)  through its management of four similar funds, the team has demonstrated its ability 
to add value to investee companies; and 
(iii)  the fund is expected to provide attractive co-investment opportunities in PSOD’s 
targeted sectors and countries. 
 
7.  Everbridge’s  proposed  investment  mandate  supports  ADB’s  development  focus  as 
evidenced by the Everbridge team’s prior investments (while at CGPM) in a range of health care 
and education initiatives, including the largest privately owned maternity hospital chain in the PRC 
by number of births (Jinxin Maternity), India’s fourth largest pharmaceutical company by domestic 
sales of chronic medicines (Intas), and an innovative education service platform for distance 
learning and vocational training in India (Manipal Global Education Services).9 Everbridge’s 
strategy also focuses on tech-enabled businesses. The rapid increase in smartphone and mobile 
broadband penetration throughout emerging Asia has driven the widespread adoption of tech-
enabled products and services. Innovative solutions are increasingly enabling companies to reach 
underserved populations in remote areas and low-income groups, and the Everbridge team has 
strategically focused on investing in businesses that benefit from this trend. Given ADB’s focus 
on promoting innovative technology and digital transformation, its relationship with Everbridge 
can provide ADB an opportunity to increase its exposure to and build domain knowledge in this 
impactful space.10 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
8.  Everbridge I will target about 10 investments in the range of $50 million to $150 million 
each, and it is expected that such investments will primarily be in segments relating to health care, 
business  services,  and  consumer  products.  The  fund  manager  will  also  actively  seek  co-
investments for transactions requiring larger equity commitments. Everbridge I expects to make 
mainly influential minority investments (ownership stake above 5% and below 50%) with a typical 
four to five year holding period for each investment.11 Everbridge seeks to invest in opportunities 
that exhibit some of the following characteristics: 
(i)  Strong, secular growth. Everbridge targets businesses that enjoy high growth 
rates with structural drivers. The fund manager will avoid businesses that are 
heavily exposed to general macroeconomic cycles, commodity cycles, and credit 
cycles.

(ii)  High-quality management teams. Everbridge invests in management teams that 
strive to be best-in-class operators, create significant value for shareholders, and 
want to establish strong governance standards. 
(iii)  Innovation  and  technology.  Technologies  such  as  mobile  broadband  are 
reshaping economies in emerging Asia. Everbridge seeks to invest in businesses 
that leverage innovation and technology to create new market demand. 
(iv)  Potential to add value. Everbridge focuses on investment targets with significant 
value-creation potential. Everbridge spends time with portfolio companies, typically 
via holding board seats, to strengthen management, financial controls, strategy, 
governance,  and  operating  processes  to  help  these  businesses  successfully 
scale.12

11.  Management. Everbridge currently consists of 16 employees, including 10 investment 
professionals, 1 compliance director, and 5 support staff, who are based either in Singapore or in 
Beijing. Everbridge anticipates hiring six additional investment professionals to support the fund’s 
operations after its initial close. In addition, Everbridge leverages a network of six operating 
partners who will support the investment team for origination, due diligence, and post-investment 
value-creation activities. 
 
12.  Governance structure. Everbridge’s investment process is organized in five stages and 
includes two investment committee meetings. 
(i)  Thematic screening. The Everbridge team develops investment themes within its 
targeted sectors and identifies the most promising companies in each industry.  
(ii)  Pipeline development. During the pipeline development stage, an initial deal 
team,  typically  consisting  of  one  senior  professional  and  one  or  two  junior 
professionals, will be formed to research the key thesis and risk factors. This stage 
may  entail  several  on-site  meetings  and  numerous  follow-up  information 
exchanges with the target company. 
(iii)  Initial investment committee review. When the relevant information is available, 
promising investment opportunities are escalated to a formal initial investment 
committee  review  session.  This  discussion  is  solely  focused  on  the  specific 
investment opportunity. If three members of the investment committee, including 
Leonard Kim, preliminarily support the opportunity, a due diligence plan and

(iv)  Investment  committee  workshop.  During  the  weeks  that  follow  the  initial 
investment committee review, the deal team will spend a significant amount of time 
engaging with the company’s management, customers, and suppliers, and will 
work  with  Capital  Group  colleagues  and  third-party  advisors  to  thoroughly 
understand  all  aspects of the  investment.  The  deal team typically  organizes 
multiple deep-dive workshops into various high-priority aspects of the investment 
opportunity  for  the  investment  committee.  Investment  committee  members 
typically give feedback after each workshop. 
(v)  Final investment committee discussion. If an investment progresses to an 
advanced stage, a final investment committee discussion will be organized. At this 
final discussion, a complete investment proposal and a compliance checklist are 
circulated. After all aspects of the investment are discussed, the  investment 
committee  will  take  a  final  vote  on  whether  to  undertake  the  investment.  A 
proposed investment must receive four affirmative votes, including that of Leonard 
Kim, to be formally approved by the investment committee. 
 
13.  Once capital is disbursed, the Everbridge team will actively engage with the investee 
company based on the agreed road map to improve the business. The tailored plans identify and 
focus on key critical areas where Everbridge can add value and drive immediate changes. 
Moreover, Everbridge reaches out to its panel of industry experts and strategic advisors to provide 
relevant advice and inputs to the investee company. Everbridge holds regular review meetings 
with the key management team of the portfolio companies and participates in board meetings. 
 
14.  Advisory committee. The fund will establish an advisory committee consisting of at least 
three  limited  partner  members  independent  of  Everbridge.  The  advisory  committee’s  remit 
includes advising on conflicts of interest, related party transactions, and valuation matters. 
Everbridge has agreed to reserve ADB a seat on the advisory committee.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
16.  ADB will provide an equity investment of up to $40,000,000 in Everbridge I. ADB’s 
proposed investment will not exceed 25% (and is not expected to exceed 10%) of the fund’s 
aggregate committed capital and will not result in ADB being the single largest investor in the 
fund. 
 
B.  Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  Exit strategy. The fund will have a 10-year term from initial closing.17 The anticipated exit 
strategies for the fund’s investments include public offerings, trade sales of portfolio companies 
to local and foreign strategic buyers, and secondary sales to other private equity funds. 
 
19.  Reporting arrangements. Everbridge will be required to provide ADB with (i) quarterly 
reports; and (ii) audited annual financial statements, an overview of the portfolio with brief 
information on each portfolio company’s performance, an annual development effectiveness 
monitoring report, and an annual environmental and social monitoring report. ADB will review this 
information and follow up with the fund manager if more information or clarification is needed. If 
the information received from the fund manager raises issues that could impair the value of ADB’s 
investment in the fund, ADB can place the fund on a watch list for more frequent review and closer 
monitoring. 
 
20.  Everbridge will be required to report annually on environmental and social safeguard 
issues in compliance with its environmental and social management system (ESMS). ADB will 
monitor the timing and quality of the safeguards reports and offer guidance if the fund manager 
requires clarification on ADB’s safeguard requirements. 
 
D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
21.  Capital mobilization and strategy validation. ADB’s participation as an initial investor 
will help anchor the fund and attract additional institutional capital to enable the fund to reach its 
target size. ADB’s investment in the fund will allow Everbridge to achieve a diversified, well-
balanced institutional investor base for the fund. In addition, ADB’s participation will provide 
validation of the fund’s strategy, and its commercial and developmental attributes. 
 
22.  Setting standards. ADB will require Everbridge to implement an ESMS acceptable to 
ADB that requires it to oblige its portfolio companies to comply with ADB’s environmental and 
social safeguard requirements and report to ADB on development indicators. ADB will support 
Everbridge in its environmental and social risk appraisal of proposed portfolio companies. 
 
23.  Gender  equality.  ADB’s  participation  will  promote  gender  equality  in  the  fund  and 
investee companies of the fund. Everbridge will work with ADB throughout the investment period 
in the design and implementation of an overarching gender policy to guide its efforts in achieving 
gender equality in its business and its investees companies, and that Everbridge will screen its 
potential investees using a gender equality scorecard developed in collaboration with ADB to 
assess their inclusiveness and diversity status and responsiveness to women’s empowerment in 
the workplace. Everbridge will be required to report annually to ADB using sex-disaggregated 
data its efforts in appraisal and management of Everbridge I portfolio companies. 
 
24.  Governance oversight. As a member of Everbridge I’s advisory committee, ADB can 
provide oversight on governance and issues relating to conflicts of interest.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
32.  Impact.  The  equity  investment  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  development 
accelerated in targeted developing member countries (DMCs) through (i) promotion of innovative 
tech-enabled businesses primarily in the health care, business services, and consumer sectors; 
and (ii) strengthened capacity of private equity markets with respect to funding volume and 
diversity of sector-specific business models. 
 
33.  Outcome. The equity investment will have the following outcome: financial sustainability 
and operational value addition of private equity investments demonstrated to benefit DMCs across 
Asia. 
 
34.  Outputs.  The  equity  investment  will  have  the  following  outputs:  (i)  Everbridge  I  is 
established, (ii) capital is invested, and (iii) Everbridge adopts a gender-inclusive approach. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
35.  Consistency  with  ADB  strategy.  The  proposed  investment  in  Everbridge  I  aligns 
strongly with two operational priorities outlined in ADB’s Strategy 2030 (footnote 10). These 
include (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by generating quality jobs, 
improving education, and achieving better health for all; and (ii) fostering regional cooperation 
and integration by enhancing connectivity and strengthening finance sector cooperation. ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 also aims to expand private sector operations to support its operational priorities 
by (i) expanding regional reach through private equity funds, (ii) strengthening the finance sector 
and capital markets, and (iii) widening geographic coverage. Given its track record with CGPM, 
Everbridge is uniquely positioned to deliver on ADB’s Strategy 2030 themes through investments 
such as Go-Jek, which promotes regional cooperation and integration, and Innovent Biologics 
and Mankind Pharma, which deliver high-quality health care products and services.

7 
36.  Consistency with country strategies. The investment in Everbridge I is aligned with 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020, which promotes finance sector 
infrastructure and supports commercially viable business models to assist in the continued 
domestic rebalancing from industry to services.18 The investment in the fund is also consistent 
with ADB’s country partnership strategy for India, 2018−2022, which includes support for the 
health sector as a strategic priority and focuses on the importance of gender equality.19 The 
investment  in  Everbridge  I  is  also  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for 
Indonesia, 2016–2019, which prioritizes inclusive growth by improving job creation, deepening 
capital markets, and investing in financial infrastructure.20 
 
37.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  proposed 
investment in Everbridge I is consistent with ADB’s plan for finance sector operations and its 
subsequent review in 2017, which prioritize improved access to capital markets and regional 
cooperation  and  integration.21 The  investment  in  the  fund  is  also  consistent  with  ADB’s 
operational plan for health, 2015–2020, which strongly supports private sector approaches to 
address quality, efficiency, and financing issues in the health sector.22 The Everbridge team’s 
experience in the health care industry and its ability to drive growth and create value in companies 
within the industry are reflected in CGPM’s investments in Jinxin Maternity and Intas (para. 7).

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
39.  Category FI. The project is classified category FI for impacts on environment, involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous people in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009). ADB has assessed the fund’s potential environmental and social impacts, the risks 
associated  with  the  existing  and  future  portfolio,  and  its  commitment  and  capacity  for 
environmental and social management as part of the safeguards due diligence process. 
 
40.  Based on review of available information (in relation to CGPM Fund IV), no past or future 
portfolio companies exhibit indicators of significant impacts or risks that would be classified as 
category  A  against  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  for  environmental,  involuntary 
resettlement, or indigenous people requirements. At the time of appraisal, Everbridge does not 
have an ESMS in place that would satisfy ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement environmental and 
social policy requirements for financial intermediaries. Everbridge will engage an independent 
external expert to develop an ESMS prior to first disbursement by ADB. The external expert will 
further support Everbridge with training. All proposed Everbridge I investments will be required to

41.  Some  gender  elements.  This  investment  is  categorized  as  having  some  gender 
elements. Everbridge recognizes the importance of gender equality in its operations and those of 
its investees, and has confirmed its willingness to implement measures to promote gender 
equality and/or women’s empowerment following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development.24 
Everbridge has indicated that it will work with ADB to implement gender inclusion and diversity 
actions, including developing and implementing a gender policy and a gender equality scorecard 
to screen all potential investees for their status and responsiveness to women’s empowerment in 
the workplace. Everbridge will be required to submit periodic reports to ADB on its efforts to 
implement gender measures including sex-disaggregated data that will include, but not be limited 
to, the number of women working at different levels in portfolio companies, and their recruitment 
and retention rates. The ESMS will set out requirements for compliance with national labor laws. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
 
42.  Everbridge was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will 
ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, 
money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism;  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
43.  The proposed equity investment is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and 
single investment exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances  
 
44.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),25 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the governments of the 
member countries of ADB where the fund will invest have no objection to the proposed assistance 
to Everbridge I. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors.

VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
45.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $40,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in Everbridge 
Partners Fund I, L.P., with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
